questions.question: What should the PT recommend to reduce the risk of other post-operative respiratory complications?
options: Frequent position changes.
Lung volume augmentation.
15 to 20 minutes of mechanical vibration.
15 to 20 minutes of range of motion exercise.

questions.question: On post-operative day four, the client is extubated and transferred to the medical unit. As the client progresses to ambulation with minimal support, the PT asks the physiotherapist assistant (PTA) to continue working with the client. Under the direction of the PT, which of the following tasks can the PTA take responsibility for?
options: Assessing the client’s impairments and functional limitations.
Discussing the results of assessment with the client and family.
Contributing to the development and revision of the physiotherapy care plan.
Establishing and monitoring the physiotherapy treatment program.

questions.question: When the PT enters the client's room on post-operative day five, the client's son tells the PT that he does not want his father to receive any further physiotherapy treatment. Which of the following actions is the BEST approach in managing this situation?
options: Ensure that the son understands the role of physiotherapy in his father’s post-surgical care.
Ask the medical team if the son has authority to withdraw consent for medical interventions.
Discuss the son’s concerns about physiotherapy at rounds and ask the medical team for input.
Leave the room and inform the client’s nurse that the son has withdrawn consent for treatment.

vignette: The remaining questions are all stand-alone questions.

questions.question: A 33-year-old woman who has multiple sclerosis attends physiotherapy at a rehabilitation centre. A physiotherapist assistant (PTA) has been assigned some parts of her care. The PTA reports to the PT that the client has made good progress in the last two weeks, and the PTA wants to add new exercises and functional tasks into the client's program. Which of the following actions should the PT take next?
options: Reassess the client.
Recommend that the client progress her program within the limits of fatigue.
Ask the PTA to reassess the client.
Advise the PTA to progress the client's program based on the PTA's observations.

questions.question: PTs in a rehabilitation centre have been using LASER to assist wound healing for over five years with excellent results. A physician in the centre, who has been strongly opposed to this, recently published a study of 15 subjects suggesting that LASER is not an effective treatment for wound healing. What should the PTs in the centre do?
options: Reject the findings because data from 15 subjects is insufficient for accurate statistical analysis.
Question the findings, because the physician's pre-research bias could have influenced the study.
Analyze the findings and combine this with information from additional sources.
Repeat the research using subjects who benefited from LASER treatment.

questions.question: A PT working in a private clinic determines that an outcome measure must be used to evaluate treatments provided for clients with work-related low-back pain who are referred from a local industry. Once the appropriate tool has been chosen for this client population, why should the PT administer and score the outcome measure following the methods described by the tool developer?
options: Because they explain the relevance of the tool for clinical decision-making.
Because they increase the participation of the client in treatment decisions.
Because they increase the reliability and validity of the tool.
Because they improve the responsiveness of the tool.

questions.question: A 25-year-old man who has hemiplegia is attending physiotherapy at a rehabilitation centre. The client says he is lonely and confides during treatment that the PT is the type of person he would like to socialize with. What should the PT do?
options: Redirect the client to the therapeutic tasks.
Arrange for another PT to see the client.
Clarify the relationship with the client.
Refer the client to a social worker.

questions.question: A PT is leading an interprofessional team that is starting up a group exercise program for adults with knee osteoarthritis. Which of the following criteria is MOST important for the PT to confirm when choosing what outcome measure to use in the program?
options: Permission to use the measure can be obtained from the developer.
The administration and scoring procedures are easy to follow.
The measures have been validated for the client population.
A technical manual or relevant documentation is available.

questions.question: A 25-year-old man was admitted to a hospital three days ago for deep partial thickness burns to his right arm. He has significant discomfort and is reluctant to move, even after the PT explains the importance of mobilization. What is the BEST course of action for the PT to take?
options: Delay mobilization until the client is less fearful.
Ask the nurse to discuss this with the physician on rounds.
Tell the client that his outcomes will be worse if he refuses to move.
Coordinate the treatment schedule with the client’s pain medication doses.

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman who has a 20-year history of relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis is being discharged from the rehabilitation unit of a community hospital after being admitted for a decline in her functional abilities. The client wants to continue with outpatient physiotherapy. In their small community, the inpatient PT is also the only private practitioner who treats clients with neurological conditions. What should the PT do?
options: Inform the client about all the alternatives and choices available.
Wait until the client is discharged before discussing the PT's private practice as an option.
Suggest that the client travel to the next nearest community for outpatient physiotherapy.
Give the client the PT's private practice business card and tell her that this is the recommended option.

questions.question: A 27-year-old woman is attending physiotherapy at a private practice clinic for recurrent anterior shoulder dislocation. During the assessment, which passive movement of the shoulder will cause the client apprehension?
options: Medial rotation at 90° of abduction.
Lateral rotation at 90° of abduction.
Lateral rotation at 90° of flexion.
Extension with medial rotation.

questions.question: A 39-year-old man has had recurrent disc protrusions, resulting in two discectomy surgeries at the L4–L5 level. Three months after his most recent surgery, he reports acute pain in sitting when the knee is extended and the spine is flexed. There is pain with a 60° straight leg raise. No other myotomal or dermatomal deficits are found. What is the MOST likely cause of the client’s symptoms?
options: Recurrent disc herniations.
Postoperative swelling.
Nerve root adhesions.
Facet joint syndrome.

questions.question: A 21-year-old man who has ankylosing spondylitis is referred for physiotherapy in a rehabilitation centre. Which of the following tests is the BEST indicator of the client’s disease progression?
options: Strength testing of upper extremity muscles.
Sensitivity to pin-prick sensory testing.
Knee, ankle, and plantar reflex testing.
Occiput-to-wall measurement test.

questions.question: A 72-year-old man is admitted to an acute care facility for a cerebrovascular accident resulting in a right flaccid hemiplegia. The client had a 2 cm (1 in) right shoulder subluxation, which was effectively reduced with the use of a full lap tray. The PT notified the team members about this protocol and documented it. For the past three days, however, the client has arrived at physiotherapy without his lap tray. His nursing attendant tells the PT, 'Everyone thinks the lap tray is too much bother.' What is the BEST course of action for the PT to take?
options: Contact the patient care coordinator to clarify the nursing attendant's statement and offer to give an in-service on the importance of positioning.
Spend time with the nursing attendant to explain the importance of reducing the subluxation and ask them to educate the other staff.
Continue using the lap tray for the client during treatment sessions and encourage other staff to do the same.
Report this incident to the patient care coordinator to express dissatisfaction with the nursing attendant.

questions.question: A 65-year-old woman who has breast cancer is admitted to an oncology ward with a fever and functional decline. She completed her third round of chemotherapy yesterday. While working with the client, the PT notices that the client's visiting granddaughter has a cold and is coughing. What should the PT tell the client's granddaughter?
options: Put on a mask.
Wash her hands.
Leave the oncology wing.
Stay outside the room during physiotherapy treatment.

questions.question: A 73-year-old man is attending physiotherapy in a hospital two days after a left total hip replacement. The PT determines that the client can understand all aspects of his care but cannot read. To ensure that the client will be able to follow his home exercise program after discharge, what is the MOST important course of action for the PT to take?
options: Arrange for a family member to read the exercise program to him at home.
Provide the client with a detailed verbal explanation of the home exercise program.
Give the client a copy of the exercise program that has illustrations of each exercise.
Ask the client to demonstrate at least one repetition of all exercises on the day of discharge.

questions.question: A 70-year-old man is admitted to an acute care hospital with severe left ventricular heart failure and pulmonary edema. Which of the following signs or symptoms should the PT expect to find during assessment?
options: Productive cough with pink, frothy sputum.
Decreased ventilation perfusion.
Decreased breath sounds.
Ascites.

questions.question: A 41-year-old woman has been attending a private physiotherapy clinic for the past six years for chronic low back pain. She asks if she can connect with the PT on social media. What should the PT tell the client?
options: It is not acceptable for a PT to use social media professionally.
It is acceptable to connect with clients on social media after they are discharged.
It is only acceptable to connect with current clients professionally on social media.
It is not acceptable under any circumstance to connect with clients on social media.

questions.question: A 60-year-old woman who had a cerebrovascular accident is enrolled in a five-week hospital physiotherapy research program. The hypothesis of the research is that, by following a specific gait training protocol, participants will be walking at a speed of at least 0.6 m/s by week five. The client achieves this speed by week three and asks for an early discharge. What should the PT do?
options: Ask the research team to talk to the client about completing the study.
Encourage the client to stay for two more weeks.
Start planning for the client's early discharge.
Remove the client from the study.

questions.question: A PT in a community-based practice is taking over the caseload of a colleague who is taking a six-month parental leave. During the PT's first session with the colleague's client who has rheumatoid arthritis, the client asks to try an alternative treatment that she saw on television. How should the PT proceed?
options: Try the alternative treatment suggested by the client.
Continue with the treatment outlined by the colleague.
Reassess the client to determine the most appropriate treatment.
Contact the client's physician regarding the new treatment suggestion.

questions.question: A 28-year-old man is referred to physiotherapy after being diagnosed with Guillain-Barré syndrome. Which of the following clinical presentations is the PT MOST likely to observe?
options: Slowly evolving, symmetrical ascending weakness.
Rapidly evolving, symmetrical ascending weakness.
Slowly evolving, asymmetrical descending weakness.
Rapidly evolving, asymmetrical ascending weakness.

questions.question: A 9-month-old baby boy has osteogenesis imperfecta. He is brought by his parents to physiotherapy at a pediatric hospital. When developing a treatment plan for the baby, which of the following interventions should the PT prioritize?
options: Parent education on proper handling and positioning techniques.
Exercises to maintain functional range of motion.
Play activities to develop trunk control.
Prescription for adaptive aids.

questions.question: A 52-year-old man attends a private physiotherapy clinic for low back pain. The PT performs an ipsilateral standing kinetic test to assess the client's sacroiliac joints. The PT places their right thumb on the client's right posterior superior iliac spine and their left thumb on the spinous process of S2. If the client has normal joint movement, what should the PT observe when the client flexes his right hip and knee to 90°?
options: The left thumb will move cranially.
The left thumb will move caudally.
The right thumb will move cranially.
The right thumb will move caudally.

questions.question: A 28-year-old woman with a three-year history of multiple sclerosis attends a private physiotherapy clinic for increased weakness and decreased endurance over the past month. Which of the following exercise factors is the MOST likely cause of these changes?
options: Doing resistance exercises using free weights.
Completing circuit training on alternate days.
Participating in sub-maximal aerobic training.
Exercising to the point of fatigue.

questions.question: A PT working in a joint replacement rehabilitation unit wants to ensure that the team's physiotherapist assistants (PTAs) are being utilized effectively. What is the BEST way for the PT to assign care to a group of PTAs with varying levels of knowledge?
options: Assign tasks based on each PTA's personal preferences.
Assign tasks based on each PTA's skills and experience.
Assign the most difficult tasks to the PTAs with the most experience.
Assign the most difficult tasks to the PTAs who completed training at an accredited college.

questions.question: A 92-year-old woman had a right cerebrovascular accident one month ago and since then has made continual improvements in her functional mobility. The PT recommends intensive inpatient rehabilitation. Her family feels that the client is “too old” for rehabilitation, and tries to convince her to return home with assistance instead. How should the PT proceed?
options: Respect the family's wishes and provide the client with a home exercise program.
Warn the client that she will lose function if she does not continue physiotherapy.
Ask the social worker to investigate the family's reluctance toward inpatient rehabilitation.
Educate the client and her family about the value of maximizing the client's level of independence.
